elements.content: A new strategy for the synthesis of inorganic–organic silver(I)-polyoxometalate materials was developed. The approach takes advantage of the ability of purine bases to build strong networks using them as ligands to silver(I). Its major experimental strong point is the facile preparation of target compounds from aqueous solutions from basic starting materials. Proof of concept was accomplished by using theobromine as the purine base. Seven new compounds containing silver(I) theobromine building blocks were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction: [Ag(thb)2]ClO4 (2), [Ag(thb)2­(H2O)]ClO4 (3), [Ag(thb)2]2­(H4V10O28)­·3H2O (4), [Ag(thb)2]2­(Cr2O7)­·0.5H2O (5), [Ag(thb)2(H2O)]2­(H3O)[Ag(β-Mo8O26)]­·4H2O (6), [Ag(thb)]2­[Ag(Cr(OH)6Mo6O18)]­·2H2O (7), and [Ag(thb)2]2(H3O)4­[Ni(OH)6Mo6O18]­(CO3)­·13H2O (8) (thb = theobromine). The purity of compounds 2–7 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction and elemental analysis. They were also characterized by IR and UV/vis spectroscopy and thermal analysis (DTA/TG). The main structural traits in all of the polyoxometalate containing compounds are coordination polymers running along the direction of one of the crystallographic axes. These chains are interconnected by a framework of strong hydrogen bonds and stacking interactions. The thermodynamic rationalization of these crystal structure landscapes is thoroughly discussed.

These chains are interconnected by a framework of strong hydrogen bonds and stacking interactions. The thermodynamic rationalization of these crystal structure landscapes is thoroughly discussed.

elements.content: Seven new compounds based on silver(I)-theobromine complexes were synthesized and characterized. Five of the compounds contain infinite chains of polyoxometalate (POM) anions interconnected by silver(I) cations. The chains are interconnected by a framework of noncovalent interactions consisting of theobromine ligands, polyoxometalates, and water molecules.

elements.content: Polyoxometalates (POMs) are oligomeric transition-metal-oxide anions, mainly built of octahedra linked by shared oxygen atoms. The metals are usually from groups 5 and 6 of the Periodic Table. These compounds are not only structurally fascinating, but found numerous applications in a multitude of areas ranging from catalysis to applications in medicine and energy generation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polyoxometalates (POMs) are oligomeric transition-metal-oxide anions, mainly built of octahedra linked by shared oxygen atoms. The metals are usually from groups 5 and 6 of the Periodic Table. These compounds are not only structurally fascinating, but found numerous applications in a multitude of areas ranging from catalysis to applications in medicine and energy generation.

elements.content: Research on silver(I) polyoxoanionic structures attracted much attention in the past decade. Much of this work has focused on understanding mechanisms of the assembly of complex inorganic–organic hybrid materials with the final aim of developing viable procedures for the synthesis of functional materials, where properties can be designed and controlled on the nanoscale. The choice of silver above other transition metals is due to its high coordinational flexibility and its affinity for POMs and N-bases as well.
elements.clean_text: Research on silver(I) polyoxoanionic structures attracted much attention in the past decade. Much of this work has focused on understanding mechanisms of the assembly of complex inorganic-organic hybrid materials with the final aim of developing viable procedures for the synthesis of functional materials, where properties can be designed and controlled on the nanoscale. The choice of silver above other transition metals is due to its high coordinational flexibility and its affinity for POMs and N-bases as well.

elements.content:
Four major synthetic strategies were developed in the course of these investigations for inorganic–organic silver(I)-isopolyoxoanions.

The most widely used synthetic approach is the synthesis of the target compounds under hydrothermal conditions. Silver(I) salts (e.g., Ag2SO4) and a binary or ternary oxide of a group 5 or 6 metal (e.g., MoO3 or Na2MoO4) are used as starting materials and an aromatic N-base as the organic component. β-Octamolybdate containing compounds obtained by this strategy are the most thoroughly described so far. The most frequent structural motifs encountered in these materials are infinite one-dimensional coordination polymers, in which octamolybdate anions are connected by silver(I) cations. These chains are interconnected by an orthogonal framework of H-bonds and π–π-stacking interactions built by the organic ligands. Reduction of the water content of the reaction mixtures yielded infinite POM chains consisting of condensed [Mo3O10]2– or [Mo4O13]2– units. These inorganic condensation polymers are surrounded by silver(I) complexes with aromatic ligands. Similar results were obtained for polyoxovanadate containing compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Four major synthetic strategies were developed in the course of these investigations for inorganic-organic silver(I)-isopolyoxoanions. 

The most widely used synthetic approach is the synthesis of the target compounds under hydrothermal conditions. Silver(I) salts (e.g., Ag2SO4) and a binary or ternary oxide of a group 5 or 6 metal (e.g., MoO3 or Na2MoO4) are used as starting materials and an aromatic N-base as the organic component. β-Octamolybdate containing compounds obtained by this strategy are the most thoroughly described so far. The most frequent structural motifs encountered in these materials are infinite one-dimensional coordination polymers, in which octamolybdate anions are connected by silver(I) cations. These chains are interconnected by an orthogonal framework of H-bonds and π-π-stacking interactions built by the organic ligands. Reduction of the water content of the reaction mixtures yielded infinite POM chains consisting of condensed [Mo3O10]2- or [Mo4O13]2- units. These inorganic condensation polymers are surrounded by silver(I) complexes with aromatic ligands. Similar results were obtained for polyoxovanadate containing compounds.

elements.content: A less widely used, but efficient, approach in the synthesis of new materials and fine-tuning of structural details is the so-called “Shrink-Wrapping Strategy” developed by Cronin et al. The content of the strategy is the reaction of POM salts of large organic cations with silver(I) salts in organic solvents. The resulting compounds contain silver(I)-POM coordination polymers, which are surrounded by the organic cations (“shrink-wrapping” the chains). Coulombic interactions between these units appear to be the detrimental stabilizing force of the crystal structures. The strategy was successfully applied to silver(I) octamolybdates, which could be arranged into 1D chains and grids as well as 2D networks depending on the reaction conditions and the cation.

The content of the strategy is the reaction of POM salts of large organic cations with silver(I) salts in organic solvents. The resulting compounds contain silver(I)-POM coordination polymers, which are surrounded by the organic cations ("shrink-wrapping" the chains). Coulombic interactions between these units appear to be the detrimental stabilizing force of the crystal structures. The strategy was successfully applied to silver(I) octamolybdates, which could be arranged into 1D chains and grids as well as 2D networks depending on the reaction conditions and the cation.

elements.content: A closely related approach was directed toward the isolation of silver(I)-POMs with solvent molecules (e.g., acetonitrile, DMSO) functioning as supporting ligands. The resulting materials are stabilized by hydrogen bonding frameworks, direct coordination of silver(I) by the POMs, and Coulombic attraction between separate silver complexes and POMs. This strategy proved especially successful for the isolation of materials containing large polyoxotungstates and decavanadate anions.
elements.clean_text: A closely related approach was directed toward the isolation of silver(I)-POMs with solvent molecules (e.g., acetonitrile, DMSO) functioning as supporting ligands. The resulting materials are stabilized by hydrogen bonding frameworks, direct coordination of silver(I) by the POMs, and Coulombic attraction between separate silver complexes and POMs. This strategy proved especially successful for the isolation of materials containing large polyoxotungstates and decavanadate anions.

elements.content: The fourth major strategy for the synthesis of inorganic–organic silver(I) isopolyoxometalates, in which the affinity of silver(I) to carboxylates is taken advantage of, was realized only for dodecatungstate containing compounds so far. The organic components applied in these reactions (e.g., nicotinic acid) bear additional carboxylate groups, which coordinate to silver(I) ions. Because of the strength of this coordinative bond, these compounds are readily accessible under relatively mild reaction conditions (80 °C) from aqueous solutions.
elements.clean_text: The fourth major strategy for the synthesis of inorganic-organic silver(I) isopolyoxometalates, in which the affinity of silver(I) to carboxylates is taken advantage of, was realized only for dodecatungstate containing compounds so far. The organic components applied in these reactions (e.g., nicotinic acid) bear additional carboxylate groups, which coordinate to silver(I) ions. Because of the strength of this coordinative bond, these compounds are readily accessible under relatively mild reaction conditions (80 °C) from aqueous solutions.

elements.content: An approach related to the four aforementioned strategies was developed for encapsulating POMs with silver(I)-alkynyl complexes. The POMs exhibit a templating effect on silver(I) ions, which in turn are coordinated by alkynyl ligands, creating a hydrophobic shell around the POM-silver(I) entities. Accordingly, the compounds are easily crystallized from polar organic solvents.
elements.clean_text: An approach related to the four aforementioned strategies was developed for encapsulating POMs with silver(I)-alkynyl complexes. The POMs exhibit a templating effect on silver(I) ions, which in turn are coordinated by alkynyl ligands, creating a hydrophobic shell around the POM-silver(I) entities. Accordingly, the compounds are easily crystallized from polar organic solvents.

elements.content: A multitude of silver(I) heteropolyoxometalate compounds was obtained following the same or similar procedures to the ones described above. A slightly different synthetic strategy was applied for the isolation of Anderson anion containing materials. These anions contain central Lewis-acidic metal cations such as Ni2+ or Cr3+, which are surrounded by a ring of six molybdate anions. Thus, inorganic complex anions of the type [M(OH6)Mo6O18] n− (M = Cr, Ni; n = 3 or 4) are readily assembled under mildly acidic conditions in aqueous solutions. Inorganic silver(I)-POMs are crystallized upon the addition of a silver(I) salt. The isolation of the respective silver(I)-POMs with organic ligands was accomplished by addition of pyridine carboxylic acid and histidine. As both ligands bear a carboxylate functionality, the strategy takes advantage of the affinity of silver(I) to carboxylates, similar to the synthetic procedures for silver(I)-dodecatungstates described above.

A slightly different synthetic strategy was applied for the isolation of Anderson anion containing materials. These anions contain central Lewis-acidic metal cations such as Ni2+ or Cr3+, which are surrounded by a ring of six molybdate anions. Thus, inorganic complex anions of the type [M(OH6)Mo6O18] n- (M = Cr, Ni; n = 3 or 4) are readily assembled under mildly acidic conditions in aqueous solutions. Inorganic silver(I)-POMs are crystallized upon the addition of a silver(I) salt. The isolation of the respective silver(I)-POMs with organic ligands was accomplished by addition of pyridine carboxylic acid and histidine. elements.content: Although the synthetic procedures described above allowed the isolation of a multitude of fascinating compounds, there are some technical drawbacks, inherent to most of them. Hydrothermal conditions require a large amount of energy and special equipment, organic solvents are usually harmful or toxic, and limitation to the compounds bearing a carboxylic acid functionality reduces the chemical flexibility.
elements.clean_text: Although the synthetic procedures described above allowed the isolation of a multitude of fascinating compounds, there are some technical drawbacks, inherent to most of them. Hydrothermal conditions require a large amount of energy and special equipment, organic solvents are usually harmful or toxic, and limitation to the compounds bearing a carboxylic acid functionality reduces the chemical flexibility.

elements.content: To tackle these challenges, we set out to develop a strategy which would allow the isolation of inorganic–organic silver(I)-POMs from aqueous solutions at room temperature. The central point of our strategy was the choice of the ligand. As the target compounds are usually stabilized by noncovalent interactions, the ligand should be capable of building a robust network of hydrogen bonds and stacking interactions as well as display high affinity to silver. Concomitantly, we deliberately did not apply ligands bearing a carboxylate group due to the above-mentioned reasons. Our choice fell on purine bases.
elements.clean_text: To tackle these challenges, we set out to develop a strategy which would allow the isolation of inorganic-organic silver(I)-POMs from aqueous solutions at room temperature. The central point of our strategy was the choice of the ligand. As the target compounds are usually stabilized by noncovalent interactions, the ligand should be capable of building a robust network of hydrogen bonds and stacking interactions as well as display high affinity to silver. Concomitantly, we deliberately did not apply ligands bearing a carboxylate group due to the above-mentioned reasons. Our choice fell on purine bases.

elements.content: Purine bases comprise a class of highly important biomolecules. It includes guanine and adenine  two of the four main constituents of DNA. The methylated xanthine derivatives caffeine, theobromine, and theophylline are notorious as coffee and chocolate ingredients and found some pharmacological applications. As commonly known for the DNA, all purines exhibit the ability to conduct strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds and stacking interactions. Judging by the extremely low solubility of their silver(I) complexes we confirmed our assumption of their high affinity to silver(I) cations. By choosing purine derivatives as ligands, we also hoped to reveal some new aspects of the chemistry of these fascinating organic molecules.

By choosing purine derivatives as ligands, we also hoped to reveal some new aspects of the chemistry of these fascinating organic molecules.

elements.content: All starting materials were purchased from commercial sources. The phase purities of bulk samples of compounds 2–7 were verified by X-ray powder diffraction on a STOE STADI transmission powder diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å; see for measured and simulated spectra). FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker IFS v/s spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. UV/vis measurements were accomplished on a Varian Cary 5E spectrophotometer using KBr pellets as well. DTA and TG analyses were performed on a Netzsch STA 409 thermal analyzer. Elemental analyses were carried out on a HEKAtech Euro EA 3000 elemental analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All starting materials were purchased from commercial sources. The phase purities of bulk samples of compounds 2-7 were verified by X-ray powder diffraction on a STOE STADI transmission powder diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å; see  for measured and simulated spectra). FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker IFS v/s spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. UV/vis measurements were accomplished on a Varian Cary 5E spectrophotometer using KBr pellets as well. DTA and TG analyses were performed on a Netzsch STA 409 thermal analyzer. Elemental analyses were carried out on a HEKAtech Euro EA 3000 elemental analyzer.

elements.content: Although powder X-ray diffraction confirms the purity of the samples, the calculated and observed values of the elemental analyses of compounds 3–7 do not match exactly. The observed values for carbon are too low. This fact can be explained by minor inorganic impurities (e.g., NaClO4) not observable in the noise of the powder X-ray diffraction patterns.

elements.content: The stock solution of theobromine for the synthesis of 4, 6, 7, and 8 was prepared as follows: Theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol) was suspended in 50 mL of H2O and brought into solution by addition of 6 mL of HClO4 (60%). The pH was adjusted to the desired values by addition of roughly 12.5 mL of NaOH solution (15%). pH values were controlled by a Bischof pH 24 pH-meter calibrated in the buffer solutions immediately before use. All pH adjustments described below were accomplished upon addition of HClO4 (60%) or NaOH (15%) solutions.

All pH adjustments described below were accomplished upon addition of HClO4 (60%) or NaOH (15%) solutions.

elements.content: Theobromine (122 mg, 0.68 mmol) was dissolved in MeOH (36 mL) by addition of HClO4 (60%, 4 mL). AgClO4 (70 mg, 0.34 mmol) in MeOH (34 mL) was added to this solution without stirring. The solution was left open in the dark and yielded colorless crystals within 10 days. The mother liquor was filtered off, and the crystals were washed twice with 10 mL portions of ice-cold MeOH and dried overnight over CaCl2 in a desiccator. Yield: 120 mg (0.21 mmol, 62%). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C14H16AgN8O8: C 29.72, H 2.49, N 19.80; found: C 29.32, H 2.94, N 20.38; IR: ν (cm–1) = 3470 (m), 3153 (m), 3123 (s), 3027 (s), 2883 (w), 2826 (s), 2750 (m), 2639 (m), 1697 (s), 1599 (s), 1551 (s), 1503 (s), 1458 (s), 1427 (s), 1365 (s), 1324 (m), 1289 (m), 1231 (s), 1201 (s), 1175 (s), 1102 (s), 1075 (s), 936 (w), 863 (m), 793 (m), 763 (m), 747 (m), 735 (m), 682 (s), 625 (s), 607 (m), 516 (s), 452 (s), 435 (m); UV/vis: λ (nm) = 201, 216, 277.

elements.content: NaVO3 (400 mg, 3.28 mmol) was suspended in 80 mL of the stock solution of theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol) of pH 4.0 and diluted with 12 mL of water. The suspension was heated to 55 °C, and the resulting pH of 5.4 was decreased to 2.6 by addition of 1.8 mL of aqueous HClO4 solution (2%). The red suspension was allowed to cool to 40 °C with stirring, and the resultant pH of 3.4 was decreased to 2.9 by addition of further 0.1 mL of aqueous HClO4 solution (2%). The yellow solution was separated from the red solid by filtration through medium-porosity filter paper. 50 mL of the aqueous solution of AgClO4 (104 mg, 0.50 mmol) was added very slowly to the reaction mixture. Orange crystals appeared after 8 days in the closed reaction vessel. Yield: 290 mg (0.15 mmol, 60% based on AgClO4). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C28H42Ag2N16O39V10: C 17.23, H 2.17, N 11.48; found: C 18.63, H 2.22, N 11.96; IR: ν (cm–1) = 3420 (br, s), 3165 (w), 3115 (m), 3032 (m), 2827 (m), 1695 (s), 1670 (s), 1593 (m), 1548 (s), 1487 (m), 1454 (m), 1367 (m), 1294 (m), 1225 (s), 1141 (s), 1112 (s), 1090 (s), 970 (m), 960 (m), 847 (m), 827 (m), 763 (w), 750 (w), 732 (w), 682 (m), 627 (m), 509 (w), 455 (m), 422 (w); UV/vis: λ (nm) = 207, 217, 277.

elements.content: The pH value of the stock solution of theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol, 69 mL) was brought to 4.5, while heating the solution to 80 °C. Na2MoO4·2H2O (730 mg, 2.97 mmol) was added to the solution, and the pH was readjusted to 4.5 with HClO4 (2%). Cr(NO3)3 (120 mg, 0.50 mmol) in 10 mL of water was added to the solution, after which AgClO4 (338 mg, 1.50 mmol) was added in 15 mL of water. A yellow solid precipitated, which was filtered off twice through 2 μm porosity filter. The yellow solid (160 mg) could not be identified by powder XRD and was discarded. A rose-colored crystalline product precipitated within a week; the mother liquor was filtered off through a Büchner funnel with suction. Yield: 430 mg (0.25 mmol, 50%). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C14H26Ag3CrN8Mo6O30: C 9.68, H 1.51, N 6.45; found: C 8.87, H 1.81, N 5.35; IR: ν (cm–1) = 3470 (br, s), 3167 (br, w), 3115 (w), 3036 (w), 2827 (w), 1693 (s), 1670 (s), 1595 (m), 1551 (s), 1487 (m), 1454 (m), 1412 (w), 1366 (m), 1294 (m), 1225 (m), 1142 (s), 1113 (s), 1087 (s), 943 (s), 889 (s), 636 (s), 575 (w), 511 (w), 413 (s). elements.content: Neat NiCO3·2Ni(OH)2·4H2O (7.5 mg, 0.02 mmol) and Na2MoO4 (99 mg, 0.4 mmol) were added to 9 mL of the stock solution of theobromine (27 mg, 0.15 mmol) of pH 3.5. The pH was adjusted to 4.5 and the solid was dissolved upon mild heating. AgClO4 (31 mg, 0.15 mmol) in 1.5 mL of water was added to the reaction mixture. After three weeks and several cycles of filtration, one yellow crystal was obtained of sufficient quality for a single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurement. Despite several attempts to upscale the reaction, the isolation of a sufficient amount of material for further analysis could not be accomplished.
elements.clean_text:
[Ag(thb)2]2(H3O)4[Ni(OH)6Mo6O18](CO3)⋅13H2O (8)

Neat NiCO3⋅2Ni(OH)2⋅4H2O (7.5 mg, 0.02 mmol) and Na2MoO4 (99 mg, 0.4 mmol) were added to 9 mL of the stock solution of theobromine (27 mg, 0.15 mmol) of pH 3.5. The pH was adjusted to 4.5 and the solid was dissolved upon mild heating. AgClO4 (31 mg, 0.15 mmol) in 1.5 mL of water was added to the reaction mixture. After three weeks and several cycles of filtration, one yellow crystal was obtained of sufficient quality for a single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurement. Despite several attempts to upscale the reaction, the isolation of a sufficient amount of material for further analysis could not be accomplished.

elements.content: Intensity data were measured at temperatures given in Table on an image-plate diffractometer, STOE IPDS I and STOE IPDS II, respectively (λ(Mo Kα) = 0.71073 Å, graphite monochromator). Structure solutions and refinements were performed using the program package WinGX, which includes the programs SHELX- and PLATON. Spherical and numerical absorption corrections were accomplished with the X-Red and X-Shape software (STOE Darmstadt). The crystal structure solution of 5 at room temperature indicated highly disordered oxygen atoms at dichromate anions. Accordingly, the atomic displacement parameters (ADPs) were quite poor. The low fraction of high-angle reflections is to be explained by the measurement on the IPDS I diffractometer and difficulties in positioning the crystal for data collection. Nevertheless, the error values R 1 and wR 2 are quite acceptable (Table ), and the measured and simulated X-ray diffraction patterns are matching (). Accordingly, we are convinced of the correctness of the structure solution. The respective argumentation regarding the ADPs applies to the low temperature phase of the compound.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Studies

Intensity data were measured at temperatures given in Table  on an image-plate diffractometer, STOE IPDS I and STOE IPDS II, respectively (λ(Mo Kα) = 0.71073 Å, graphite monochromator). Structure solutions and refinements were performed using the program package WinGX, which includes the programs SHELX- and PLATON. Spherical and numerical absorption corrections were accomplished with the X-Red and X-Shape software (STOE Darmstadt). The crystal structure solution of 5 at room temperature indicated highly disordered oxygen atoms at dichromate anions. Accordingly, the atomic displacement parameters (ADPs) were quite poor. The low fraction of high-angle reflections is to be explained by the measurement on the IPDS I diffractometer and difficulties in positioning the crystal for data collection. Nevertheless, the error values R 1 and wR 2 are quite acceptable (Table ), and the measured and simulated X-ray diffraction patterns are matching (). Accordingly, we are convinced of the correctness of the structure solution. The respective argumentation regarding the ADPs applies to the low temperature phase of the compound.

elements.content: Theobromine (thb) (1) was chosen among the purine bases for the present work as it combines an acceptable solubility with the ability to build amide-to-amide H-bonding interactions building symmetrical dimers (via N1–H and O6; see Figure for atom numbering) and for its affinity to silver(I), by coordination via N9. The purine molecule is capable of stacking interactions as well, stabilizing the crystal structures containing theobromine in the third dimension.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthetic Strategy

Theobromine (thb) (1) was chosen among the purine bases for the present work as it combines an acceptable solubility with the ability to build amide-to-amide H-bonding interactions building symmetrical dimers (via N1-H and O6; see Figure  for atom numbering) and for its affinity to silver(I), by coordination via N9. The purine molecule is capable of stacking interactions as well, stabilizing the crystal structures containing theobromine in the third dimension.

elements.content: Despite these fortunate properties, sufficient amounts of theobromine can be dissolved in most solvents only upon addition of a strong acid or base. Perchloric acid was chosen as a strong acid with a weakly coordinating conjugate base. The perchlorate anion does not disturb crystallization by coordinating to silver(I) in the solution and does not coordinate to Ag+ in silver(I)-theobromine complexes in the solid state (see “Structure Description” for a detailed discussion).

elements.content: [Ag(thb)2]ClO4 (2) and [Ag(thb)2(H2O)]ClO4 (3) were obtained by crystallization from methanolic (2) and aqueous (3) solutions, respectively, of theobromine and silver(I) perchlorate acidified by perchloric acid. Addition of sodium dichromate(VI) to a strongly acidified solution of silver(I) nitrate and theobromine yielded [Ag(thb)2]2(Cr2O7)­·0.5H2O (5). The formation of 5 even under strongly acidic conditions, under which theobromine molecules are protonated, hints at the high thermodynamic stability of the compound. The largest contribution to its stability should be expected from silver(I)-dichromate interactions.

elements.content: Accidentally, we discovered that after neutralizing acidic theobromine solutions with NaOH, the purine base does not precipitate right away but remains in solution for days or even weeks. It might very well be the case that the increased solvent polarity, due to NaClO4, dissolved in the solution as a result of the neutralization, kinetically hinders the precipitation. The assumption is reinforced by the fact that after dissolving theobromine in distilled water by heating, it reprecipitates after cooling to room temperature quite rapidly.

elements.content: Despite obvious chemical similarities between 2 and 3, the H-bonding frameworks, stabilizing their structures, are significantly different (Figure ). 2 is stabilized by amide-to-amide H-bonds between theobromine ligands (N···O 2.8481(3) Å, N–H···O 173.50(1)°), geometrically similar to the adenine-thymine base pair in DNA. These dimers are readily built by theobromine molecules and are encountered in the subsequently described compounds 4–6 with approximately the same geometry.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

[Ag(thb)2]ClO4 (2) and [Ag(thb)2(H2O)]ClO4 (3)

Despite obvious chemical similarities between 2 and 3, the H-bonding frameworks, stabilizing their structures, are significantly different (Figure ). 2 is stabilized by amide-to-amide H-bonds between theobromine ligands (N⋅⋅⋅O 2.8481(3) Å, N-H⋅⋅⋅O 173.50(1)°), geometrically similar to the adenine-thymine base pair in DNA. These dimers are readily built by theobromine molecules and are encountered in the subsequently described compounds 4-6 with approximately the same geometry.

elements.content: The H atom bound to C8 is quite acidic, due to neighboring N atoms of the imidazole ring and accordingly conducts H-bonding interactions with the perchlorate oxygen atoms (Figure a). These interactions are rather weak due to the low electronegativity difference between C and H and accordingly are not suitable to attenuate the thermal motion of the accepting oxygen atoms. The structural stabilization in the third dimension is facilitated by stacking interactions between theobromine molecules (not shown, see below for a thorough discussion).

elements.content: The H-bond framework of 3 is not built by self-pairing theobromine ligands but shows a different pattern of H-bonding interactions (Figure b). The carbonyl oxygen atom O6 conducts an H-bond to the water molecule coordinating to silver(I), while the amide proton is donated to perchlorate oxygen atoms. This N1–H1···O–Cl noncovalent interaction is obviously stronger than the corresponding C8–H8···O–Cl bond in 2, as now the perchlorate oxygen atoms are held firmly in place (compare Figure , panels a and b). This framework extends in two dimensions and is stabilized by stacking interactions of theobromine molecules in the third dimension (not shown, see below).

elements.content: The distances between Ag+ and C3 of the theobromine ligand in 2 and 3 (3.39 and 3.43 Å, respectively) are both shorter than the sum of the van-der-Waals radii of Ag+ and a methyl group (3.72 Å). It is not clear if an agostic interaction exists between silver(I) and one of the protons of the methyl group, or if this close distance is simply brought by the covalent theobromine framework. In any case, a strong interaction is not expected as it apparently does not significantly influence the complex geometry. Accordingly, Ag–H interactions in 2, 3, and all of the subsequent compounds are not indicated.

elements.content: The basic principle of the frameworks of hydrogen bonds in the POM-based compounds 4–6 is quite similar to 2 and 3, despite the more complex large anions. All three compounds exhibit two crystallographically different theobromine ligands. The hydrogen-bonding interactions built by these molecules with surrounding entities can be considered a mixture of the networks of intermolecular interactions of 2 and 3. One theobromine ligand stabilizes the structure by building amide-to-amide dimers and the other one conducts H-bonds either directly to POM anions or to water molecules. The stacking interactions perpendicular to the hydrogen bonds are also quite common. Theobromine molecules conduct additional stacking interactions with the POM anions, which are discussed below for each compound individually.
elements.clean_text:
Isopolyoxometalate-Based Materials

The basic principle of the frameworks of hydrogen bonds in the POM-based compounds 4-6 is quite similar to 2 and 3, despite the more complex large anions. All three compounds exhibit two crystallographically different theobromine ligands. The hydrogen-bonding interactions built by these molecules with surrounding entities can be considered a mixture of the networks of intermolecular interactions of 2 and 3. One theobromine ligand stabilizes the structure by building amide-to-amide dimers and the other one conducts H-bonds either directly to POM anions or to water molecules. The stacking interactions perpendicular to the hydrogen bonds are also quite common. Theobromine molecules conduct additional stacking interactions with the POM anions, which are discussed below for each compound individually.

elements.content: The decavanadate(V) ions, [H4V10O28]2–, in 4 are interconnected via silver(I) ions and hydrogen bonds building coordination polymers running along the crystallographic a-axis (Figure ). The hydrogen bonds are built between the protonated and deprotonated oxygen atoms of the adjacent decavanadate(V) anions. The exact positions of the protons between the decavanadate(V) anions could not be detected, but the interatomic distances around 3.05 Å between the oxygen atoms of the adjacent POMs indicate hydrogen bonding of medium strength. Charge balance considerations demand four protons shared between two decavanadate(V) anions, but there are altogether six pairs of oxygen atoms located within hydrogen-bonding distances from each other. X-ray diffraction analysis does not allow determining whether the protons are shared between four of these pairs or delocalized over all six.

[Ag(thb)2]2[H4V10O28]⋅3H2O (4)

The hydrogen bonds are built between the protonated and deprotonated oxygen atoms of the adjacent decavanadate(V) anions. The exact positions of the protons between the decavanadate(V) anions could not be detected, but the interatomic distances around 3.05 Å between the oxygen atoms of the adjacent POMs indicate hydrogen bonding of medium strength. Charge balance considerations demand four protons shared between two decavanadate(V) anions, but there are altogether six pairs of oxygen atoms located within hydrogen-bonding distances from each other. X-ray diffraction analysis does not allow determining whether the protons are shared between four of these pairs or delocalized over all six.

elements.content: The theobromine ligands accomplish the interconnections between the chains via hydrogen bonding and stacking interactions as shown in Figure . One of the crystallographically different theobromine molecules resides virtually parallel to one of the faces of decavanadate(V) ion (Figure a, interplanar angle: ca. 4.5°). Given a distance of 2.99–3.34 Å between the decavanadate(V) face and aromatic atoms of the purine ring, anion-π interactions are suggested. We will discuss the energetic consequences of this geometry below.

elements.content: The main structure defining motifs of 5 are Ag(I)-Cr2O7 chains running along the crystallographic a-axis (Figure ). The silver(I) cations connect dichromate(VI) units pairwise, such that an 8-ring consisting of 2 Ag, 2 Cr, and 4 O atoms is built. The terminal oxygen atoms are disordered in a ratio of 64% to 36%, due to thermal motions of the dichromate ions. Positions of the internal oxygen atoms of dichromate(VI) were split 50%/50%, due to overlapping thermal movements of the two parts of dichromate(VI) in opposite directions.

elements.content: In order to attenuate the thermal motion of the dichromate(VI) anions, single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed at low temperatures. During data collection, a phase transition of 5 was detected. The temperature of the phase transition was determined by DSC analysis (). Despite the very low heat exchange, indicating a second-order phase transition, the transition temperature could be determined to be −83.2 °C.

Despite the very low heat exchange, indicating a second-order phase transition, the transition temperature could be determined to be -83.2 °C.

elements.content: Structure determination at −173 °C yielded also a triclinic unit cell, but nearly four times as big as the room temperature cell (unit cell volume: 3980 Å3 vs 1027 Å3 at room temperature). Accordingly, Z is increased from 1 to 4. Despite this reduction in symmetry, which is quite common in phase transitions from higher to lower temperatures, the silver(I)-dichromate(VI) chains, described above, remain the main structure building motif (Figure ). As expected for a second-order phase transition, no fundamental changes in the crystal structure occur. The essential distinction of the low temperature modification is that the chains consist of alternating seven- and eight-membered rings of Ag, Cr, and O atoms and run along the crystallographic c-axis (Figure ). The Ag atoms occupy four different crystallographic positions. Two of these crystallographically inequivalent Ag atoms are interconnected by one O atom of dichromate in seven-membered rings, and the other two build eight-membered rings.

elements.content: Similar to the previously described compounds, silver(I) octamolybdate(VI) chains connected by a framework consisting of H-bonds between self-pairing theobromine ligands, and H-bonds between theobromine ligands, water molecules, and POMs, are the main structural features of 6. Nonetheless, there are some distinct characteristics of 6.
elements.clean_text:
[Ag(thb)2(H2O)]2(H3O)[Ag(β-Mo8O26)]⋅4H2O (6)

Similar to the previously described compounds, silver(I) octamolybdate(VI) chains connected by a framework consisting of H-bonds between self-pairing theobromine ligands, and H-bonds between theobromine ligands, water molecules, and POMs, are the main structural features of 6. Nonetheless, there are some distinct characteristics of 6.

elements.content: The first remarkable feature of 6 is that every octamolybdate(VI) is surrounded by a frame of theobromine ligands (Figure a). Stacking interactions between theobromine and the polyoxomolybdate anion appear to be quite strong, not only due to the short interplanar distances between ligand and the parallel POM surface (Figure a), but also judging on the extremely bent geometry of the ditheobromine–silver(I) complexes (NAgN: 137.166(1)°). The second remarkable aspect is the interconnection of octamolybdate(VI) anions via three silver(I) ions (Figure b); the usual case is one or two. The central silver(I) ion displays a coordination number of 8 surrounded by four pairs of oxygen atoms from two different octamolybdate(VI) anions. The whole chain running along the crystallographic c-axis can be considered as one infinite POM, the central silver(I)-cations being part of the polyoxoanionic framework.

elements.content: In both [Ag(thb)]2­[AgCr(OH)6Mo6O18]­·2H2O (7) and [Ag(thb)2]2(H3O)4[Ni(OH)6Mo6O18](CO3)·13H2O (8), there are no amide-to-amide dimers of theobromine. Ditheobromine silver(I) complexes are not encountered in 7, substituted for monotheobromine–silver(I) moieties H-bonded to the POM. On the other hand, the ditheobromine–silver(I) complexes are encountered in 8. Because of the large amount of water molecules in the crystal structure of this compound, the whole framework is distinctly different from the isopolyoxometalate based compounds 4–6.
elements.clean_text:
Anderson-Anion Based Materials

In both [Ag(thb)]2[AgCr(OH)6Mo6O18]⋅2H2O (7) and [Ag(thb)2]2(H3O)4[Ni(OH)6Mo6O18](CO3)⋅13H2O (8), there are no amide-to-amide dimers of theobromine. Ditheobromine silver(I) complexes are not encountered in 7, substituted for monotheobromine-silver(I) moieties H-bonded to the POM. On the other hand, the ditheobromine-silver(I) complexes are encountered in 8. Because of the large amount of water molecules in the crystal structure of this compound, the whole framework is distinctly different from the isopolyoxometalate based compounds 4-6.

elements.content: Both differences can be accounted for by the central cations of the Anderson anions. The strongly Lewis acidic Cr3+ in [Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]3– renders the charge of the whole complex anion low and accordingly prone to build coordination bonds to silver(I), which can be considered hard interactions compared to hydrogen bonding. On the other hand, the less Lewis acidic Ni2+ with a lower positive charge renders the charge of the Anderson anion of 4– in 8. Accordingly, the softer H-bonding interactions with water are more readily built by [Ni(OH)6Mo6O18]4–.

elements.content: The only familiar structural traits of 7 are chains of the Anderson anions running along the crystallographic b-axis. The anions are interconnected via hydrogen bonding between the protonated oxygen atoms of the central anionic moiety and the not protonated oxygen atoms on the periphery of the anion (Figure ). Additionally, the anions build coordinative bonds to silver(I) cations which interconnect the chains. The plains of the so-connected Anderson anions build an angle of 84° with each other. One crystallographically different silver(I) cation is coordinated to the theobromine molecule (right part of Figure ). It is disordered due to the surrounding by eight oxygen ligands, one of which is an oscillating water molecule, and one nitrogen ligand (). The theobromine ligand builds a hydrogen bond with its amide proton to an Anderson anion, accomplishing a hydrogen bond connection of two adjacent chains.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 8 contains a lattice built by Anderson anions interconnected by silver(I) in the c-axis direction and theobromine ligands connecting the silver(I)-POM chains in two orthogonal directions (Figure ). This lattice serves as a frame for voids of a cuboid shape (Figure b, ). These “boxes” measure (14.5 × 12.1 × 6.2) Å3, and each one includes 13 water molecules, 4 hydronium ions and one carbonate ion.

elements.content: The hydrogen-bonding framework of 8 is significantly different from that of 2–6. There are two crystallographically different theobromine ligands. The amide hydrogen atom of one of these ligands conducts a hydrogen bond to the carbonyl group of another one (Figure , top). The plains of the molecules are twisted by 63.7° with respect to one another. Accordingly, there is only one hydrogen bond possible. The hydrogen bond distance and angle indicate a hydrogen-bonding interaction of intermediate strength (N1···O16T 2.8184(3) Å, N1–H1···O16T 174.66(1)°).

elements.clean_text:
Structural and Energetic Analysis

The reactions leading to the synthesis of the presented compounds can be considered as self-assembly of complex building blocks and simple chemical units: silver(I) ions, theobromine, water molecules, and POMs. We consider energetic rationalization of the resulting crystal structures an important task, as it allows for the design of further compounds on the basis of the obtained ones.

elements.content: The self-assembly of all presented crystal structures can be traced back to four organizing forces: coordinative bonding, hydrogen bonding, as well stacking interactions between aromatic molecules and the so-called anion-π stacking interactions.
elements.clean_text: The self-assembly of all presented crystal structures can be traced back to four organizing forces: coordinative bonding, hydrogen bonding, as well stacking interactions between aromatic molecules and the so-called anion-π stacking interactions.

elements.content: Silver(I) ions and theobromine molecules build ditheobromine–silver(I) complexes in almost all compounds discussed above (see Figures – and ). Additionally, the metal ions are coordinated to POMs, connecting them to one-dimensional chains. The Ag–N and Ag–O coordination bond lengths are within the respective ranges of 2.14–2.28 Å and 2.57–2.80 Å for all compounds. The minor differences in the bond lengths between the individual compounds are easily explained by a different ligand sphere or POM geometry.

elements.content: The hydrogen-bond networks in 2–8 are quite robust and primarily formed by interactions of the amide group of theobromine either with an equivalent group or with a hydrogen-bond acceptor such as perchlorate or POM. The distances between the N1-amide hydrogen-bond donor and the O2-carbonyl acceptor in the amide-to-amide dimers are around 2.85 Å, and the N1–H1···O2 angles are nearly 180°. These distances and angles are similar to those between hydrogen-bonded atoms of the adenine–thymine base pair (2.85–2.92 Å), which also shows two hydrogen bonds and a similar geometry. The experimental value for the enthalpy of the adenine–thymine interactions was determined to amount to −12.1 kcal/mol (50.6 kJ/mol).

elements.content: To be more certain regarding the energetic value of amide-to-amide theobromine dimers, we used the PACHA (Partial atomic charges and hardness analysis) software for energetic evaluation. This is a facile theoretical approach based on spherical approximation of density functional equations. The main advantages over other theoretical approaches evaluating solid-state structures are the usage of the atomic and crystal parameters from the CIF files and the speed of calculations. The energetic evaluation of supramolecular interactions using PACHA is based on the quantity called “electrostatic balance”.

elements.content: In order to determine the energetic contribution of hydrogen bonds, the electrostatic balance of two amide-to-amide bound [Ag(thb)2]+ complexes was calculated and twice the electrostatic balance of the individual [Ag(thb)2]+ complexes in 2 subtracted. The obtained value of −43.1 kJ/mol is at the same order of magnitude as the value obtained for adenine–thymine interactions stated above. As hydrogen-bond geometries between the amide group of theobromine and other interaction partners are quite similar, we consider their stabilization energies to contribute similar amounts.

elements.content: Stacking interactions of purine bases remained an area of continuous scientific interest throughout the past decade, due to its biological significance. Quite profound theoretical and experimental investigations of theobromine dimers in the gas phase were accomplished by de Vries et al. The stacked theobromine dimer of similar geometry to that displayed in Figure was assessed to be the most stable form of theobromine–theobromine interactions in the gas phase by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, which were verified by experimental results. The stacked dimer was estimated to be more stable than the amide-to-amide dimer by 4.3 kcal/mol. This rather surprising result is caused by the attractive dipole–dipole interactions between the carbonyl carbon atom of one theobromine ligand with the methylated nitrogen atom of the other (Figure ). This attraction between electron-poor carbon and electron-rich nitrogen is much stronger than the repulsion between the methyl groups of the stacked theobromine molecules. Accordingly, the interplanar distance of the parallel theobromine molecules in compounds 2–6 is generally shorter than 3.3 Å, which is even less than the respective mean distance between DNA bases (3.4 Å).

elements.content: The determination of the stabilization enthalpy of stacked theobromine dimers with the PACHA software based on the crystal structure of 2 yielded a value of −49.8 kJ/mol. This value illustrates that the stacking interactions in the synthesized compounds are even slightly more detrimental for the structural landscape than the amide-to-amide interactions discussed above.

elements.content: Anion-π interactions of significant stabilizing power have gained a lot of attention in the past decade. Exploration of the interactions between anions and nucleic bases were in the focus of this research due to their significance to the stabilization of the RNA. These forces are extremely sensitive toward the π-acidity of the aromatic rings with which they interact. For instance, the interactions between a phosphate residue and guanine were determined by ab initio calculations to destabilize the system by ≈20 kJ/mol, whereas the interactions of the same anion with a uracil ring are equally stabilizing.
elements.clean_text: Anion-π interactions of significant stabilizing power have gained a lot of attention in the past decade. Exploration of the interactions between anions and nucleic bases were in the focus of this research due to their significance to the stabilization of the RNA. These forces are extremely sensitive toward the π-acidity of the aromatic rings with which they interact. For instance, the interactions between a phosphate residue and guanine were determined by ab initio calculations to destabilize the system by ~20 kJ/mol, whereas the interactions of the same anion with a uracil ring are equally stabilizing.

elements.content: The theobromine ring system is π-acidic due to the electronegative nitrogen atoms and carbonyl groups comprising the purine molecule. In 2–8, this π-acidity is increased by coordination to silver(I) cations. It is therefore not surprising that the interaction energy between a theobromine ring and four oxygen atoms defining the parallel POM face in 6 was calculated to amount to −113.65 kJ/mol (see Figure for the respective geometry of 6 and for the PACHA calculations). This value is more than twice as high as the respective H-bonding and theobromine–theobromine stacking interactions and, hence, the strong distortion of the geometry of the [Ag(thb)2]+ complexes comes as no surprise in 6.

elements.content: These interactions obviously become less significant with increasing temperature. A large evolution of heat is observed in the DTA curves of compounds 4–7 in the temperature range 240–300 °C (). This emission of heat is accompanied by a strong loss of mass in the TG curve (30–50%). Both observations can be explained by an exothermic intramolecular redox reaction in the course of which the ligand reduces Ag+ and POMs and is oxidized to gaseous products (most likely carbon dioxide, nitrogen, and water).

elements.content: First silver(I)-purine POMs were synthesized setting an example of the successful application of transition metal complexes of purines for the construction of POM-based supramolecular materials. In order to accomplish the synthesis, a new strategy was developed and successfully applied. In general terms, the experimental aspects of the strategy include dissolution of the poorly soluble theobromine ligand in acidic media, pH adjustment to the desired value, and addition of the POM-building salt. The subsequent addition of a silver(I) salt induces precipitation of the target compound.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

First silver(I)-purine POMs were synthesized setting an example of the successful application of transition metal complexes of purines for the construction of POM-based supramolecular materials. In order to accomplish the synthesis, a new strategy was developed and successfully applied. In general terms, the experimental aspects of the strategy include dissolution of the poorly soluble theobromine ligand in acidic media, pH adjustment to the desired value, and addition of the POM-building salt. The subsequent addition of a silver(I) salt induces precipitation of the target compound.

elements.content: According to our intentions, the general advantage of the described synthetic approach is its simplicity. The POMs are assembled in situ from the basic inorganic materials in aqueous solutions. The target materials are isolated by crystallization after addition of theobromine and silver(I) solutions to these reaction mixtures. The procedures do not require any precursors, organic solvents, or high temperatures necessary for hydrothermal conditions.
elements.clean_text: According to our intentions, the general advantage of the described synthetic approach is its simplicity. The POMs are assembled in situ from the basic inorganic materials in aqueous solutions. The target materials are isolated by crystallization after addition of theobromine and silver(I) solutions to these reaction mixtures. The procedures do not require any precursors, organic solvents, or high temperatures necessary for hydrothermal conditions.

elements.content: The main organizing forces stabilizing the target materials are the N–Ag+ and O–Ag+ coordinative bonds as well as noncovalent interactions between theobromine ligands and between theobromine ligands and polyoxoanions. The hydrogen-bonding framework of the structures is dominated by amide-to-amide theobromine dimers as well as amide-to-POM/water hydrogen bonds. π–π and anion-π stacking interactions are observed and considered to contribute to the overall structural stabilization quite appreciably. All isopolyoxometalate-based structures contain silver(I)-POM coordination polymers interconnected by these noncovalent interactions. The Anderson anion based materials display two different structural landscapes depending on the Lewis acid in the center of the anion. In the case of the hard Lewis acid Cr3+, the POM content of the compound is increased, and the stabilizing effect of the ligand is less pronounced than in the isopolyoxometalate-containing materials. The softer Lewis acid Ni2+ induces building of a MOF stabilized by noncovalent interactions, which contains rectangular boxes filled with water molecules and carbonate.

The softer Lewis acid Ni2+ induces building of a MOF stabilized by noncovalent interactions, which contains rectangular boxes filled with water molecules and carbonate.

elements.content: We consider the developed strategy to be applicable to further molecules of the class of purine bases. Adenine, guanine, and xanthine appear especially interesting ligands due to their ability to build robust networks based on hydrogen bonding and stacking interactions as well as a multitude of potentially coordinating atoms. Thus, further research efforts will be directed toward the synthesis of their silver(I)-POM based compounds using the same approach.

elements.content: We further consider the strategic approach applicable to the construction of materials based on other POMs. Future efforts are aimed at the synthesis and isolation of silver(I)-purine-W(VI)-, Nb(V)-, and Ta(V)-POMs. In particular, materials based on POMs of the heavier elements of the fifth group of the Periodic Table will be in focus, as no Ag(I)–Nb(V) nor −Ta(V) POM has been isolated so far.

References

There are iso- and hetero-POMs. Isopolyoxoanions comprise the class of POMs, in which only one kind of metallic element is present. The class of hetero-POMs includes anions with two or more different metals or a metal and a main group element other than oxygen.

cln_elements.content:
The stock solution of theobromine for the synthesis of 4, 6, 7, and 8 was prepared as follows: Theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol) was suspended in 50 mL of H2O and brought into solution by addition of 6 mL of HClO4 (60%). The pH was adjusted to the desired values by addition of roughly 12.5 mL of NaOH solution (15%). pH values were controlled by a Bischof pH 24 pH-meter calibrated in the buffer solutions immediately before use. All pH adjustments described below were accomplished upon addition of HClO4 (60%) or NaOH (15%) solutions.

[Ag(thb)<sub>2</sub>]ClO<sub>4</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Theobromine (122 mg, 0.68 mmol) was dissolved in MeOH (36 mL) by addition of HClO4 (60%, 4 mL). AgClO4 (70 mg, 0.34 mmol) in MeOH (34 mL) was added to this solution without stirring. The solution was left open in the dark and yielded colorless crystals within 10 days. The mother liquor was filtered off, and the crystals were washed twice with 10 mL portions of ice-cold MeOH and dried overnight over CaCl2 in a desiccator. Yield: 120 mg (0.21 mmol, 62%). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C14H16AgN8O8: C 29.72, H 2.49, N 19.80; found: C 29.32, H 2.94, N 20.38; IR: ν (cm–1) = 3470 (m), 3153 (m), 3123 (s), 3027 (s), 2883 (w), 2826 (s), 2750 (m), 2639 (m), 1697 (s), 1599 (s), 1551 (s), 1503 (s), 1458 (s), 1427 (s), 1365 (s), 1324 (m), 1289 (m), 1231 (s), 1201 (s), 1175 (s), 1102 (s), 1075 (s), 936 (w), 863 (m), 793 (m), 763 (m), 747 (m), 735 (m), 682 (s), 625 (s), 607 (m), 516 (s), 452 (s), 435 (m); UV/vis: λ (nm) = 201, 216, 277.

[Ag(thb)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]ClO<sub>4</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol) was dissolved in 50 mL of water by addition of 6 mL of 60%-HClO4. AgClO4 (104 mg, 0.50 mmol) in water (50 mL) was added to this solution with stirring all at once. The solution was left open for two months, after which the mother liquor was filtered off, and the obtained colorless crystals were washed twice with 10 mL portions of cold water. 95 mg of 3 were obtained after drying overnight over CaCl2 in a desiccator. Yield: 95 mg (0.16 mmol, 32%). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C14H18AgClN8O9: C 29.60, H 2.82, N 19.73; found: C 28.25, H 3.00, N 19.72; IR: ν (cm–1) = 3582 (m), 3522 (m), 3371 (w), 3240 (s), 3122 (s), 3123 (s), 3070 (m), 2957 (w), 2827 (w), 2779 (w), 1695 (s), 1595 (s), 1551 (s), 1501 (s), 1464 (s), 1414 (m), 1366 (s), 1315 (w), 1285 (w), 1221 (s), 1082 (s), 937 (w), 874 (w), 789 (m), 744 (s), 681 (m), 615 (s), 515 (m), 449 (s).

[Ag(thb)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>4</sub>V<sub>10</sub>O<sub>28</sub>)·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

NaVO3 (400 mg, 3.28 mmol) was suspended in 80 mL of the stock solution of theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol) of pH 4.0 and diluted with 12 mL of water. The suspension was heated to 55 °C, and the resulting pH of 5.4 was decreased to 2.6 by addition of 1.8 mL of aqueous HClO4 solution (2%). The red suspension was allowed to cool to 40 °C with stirring, and the resultant pH of 3.4 was decreased to 2.9 by addition of further 0.1 mL of aqueous HClO4 solution (2%). The yellow solution was separated from the red solid by filtration through medium-porosity filter paper. 50 mL of the aqueous solution of AgClO4 (104 mg, 0.50 mmol) was added very slowly to the reaction mixture. Orange crystals appeared after 8 days in the closed reaction vessel. Yield: 290 mg (0.15 mmol, 60% based on AgClO4). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C28H42Ag2N16O39V10: C 17.23, H 2.17, N 11.48; found: C 18.63, H 2.22, N 11.96; IR: ν (cm–1) = 3420 (br, s), 3165 (w), 3115 (m), 3032 (m), 2827 (m), 1695 (s), 1670 (s), 1593 (m), 1548 (s), 1487 (m), 1454 (m), 1367 (m), 1294 (m), 1225 (s), 1141 (s), 1112 (s), 1090 (s), 970 (m), 960 (m), 847 (m), 827 (m), 763 (w), 750 (w), 732 (w), 682 (m), 627 (m), 509 (w), 455 (m), 422 (w); UV/vis: λ (nm) = 207, 217, 277.

[Ag(thb)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>(Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)·0.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

Theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol) was dissolved in 50 mL of water by addition of 5 mL of 60%-HClO4. Na2Cr2O7 (262 mg, 1.00 mmol) was dissolved in 35 mL of H2O and added to the theobromine solution. AgClO4 (207 mg, 1.00 mmol) in water (50 mL) was added to the reaction mixture without stirring. After 1 day, orange block-shaped crystals precipitated. The mother liquor was decanted after 1 week, the crystals dried overnight over CaCl2 in a desiccator. Yield: 120 mg (0.10 mmol, 40% based on theobromine). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C28H33Ag2Cr2N16O15.5: C 28.75, H 2.74, N 19.17; found: C 27.70, H 3.14, N 19.53; IR: ν (cm–1) = 3601 (w), 3526 (w), 3119 (m), 3028 (s), 2826 (w), 2791 (m), 1707 (s), 1672 (s), 1601 (m), 1549 (s), 1468 (w), 1414 (w), 1363 (m), 1313 (m), 1288 (m), 1231 (m), 1198 (m), 1141 (m), 1082 (w), 1043 (w), 935 (s), 878 (w), 845 (w), 677 (m), 744 (m), 609 (m), 515 (m), 449 (m). UV/vis: λ (nm) = 205, 276, 380.

[Ag(thb)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>3</sub>O)­[Ag(β-Mo<sub>8</sub>O<sub>26</sub>)]­·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>6</bold>)

45 mL of the stock solution of theobromine (108 mg, 0.60 mmol) of pH 3.1 was added to the solution of Na2MoO4 (443 mg, 1.8 mmol) in 60 mL of water at pH 4.5. AgClO4 (124 mg, 0.6 mmol) dissolved in 6 mL of water was added over the course of 15 min to the reaction mixture. The final pH was adjusted to 4.0. The yellow solution was filtered after 5 h. The yellow residue was discarded. The reaction mixture was left in the fume hood closed by perforated PARAFILM for three weeks, during which the product crystallized in yellow blocks. Yield: 42 mg (0.02 mmol, 13% based on theobromine). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C28H47Ag3Mo8N16O41: C 14.28, H 2.01, N 9.52; found: C 13.32, H 2.11, N 8.95; IR: ν (cm–1) = 3458 (br, s), 3121 (w), 3036 (w), 2837 (m), 1693 (br, s), 1597 (w), 1553 (m), 1497 (m), 1456 (w), 1425 (w), 1367 (m), 1292 (w), 1227 (m), 1199 (w), 1144 (s), 1117 (s), 1089 (s), 943 (m), 912 (m), 837 (m), 715 (br, m), 685 (w), 627 (m), 555 (w), 515 (m), 455 (w), 411 (w). UV/vis: λ (nm) = 208, 222, 288.

[Ag(thb)]<sub>2</sub>[Ag(Cr(OH)<sub>6</sub>Mo<sub>6</sub>O<sub>18</sub>)]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>7</bold>)

The pH value of the stock solution of theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol, 69 mL) was brought to 4.5, while heating the solution to 80 °C. Na2MoO4·2H2O (730 mg, 2.97 mmol) was added to the solution, and the pH was readjusted to 4.5 with HClO4 (2%). Cr(NO3)3 (120 mg, 0.50 mmol) in 10 mL of water was added to the solution, after which AgClO4 (338 mg, 1.50 mmol) was added in 15 mL of water. A yellow solid precipitated, which was filtered off twice through 2 μm porosity filter. The yellow solid (160 mg) could not be identified by powder XRD and was discarded. UV/vis: λ (nm) = 218, 272.

[Ag(thb)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>3</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>­[Ni(OH)<sub>6</sub>Mo<sub>6</sub>O<sub>18</sub>]­(CO<sub>3</sub>)·13H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>8</bold>)

Neat NiCO3·2Ni(OH)2·4H2O (7.5 mg, 0.02 mmol) and Na2MoO4 (99 mg, 0.4 mmol) were added to 9 mL of the stock solution of theobromine (27 mg, 0.15 mmol) of pH 3.5. The pH was adjusted to 4.5 and the solid was dissolved upon mild heating. AgClO4 (31 mg, 0.15 mmol) in 1.5 mL of water was added to the reaction mixture. After three weeks and several cycles of filtration, one yellow crystal was obtained of sufficient quality for a single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurement. Despite several attempts to upscale the reaction, the isolation of a sufficient amount of material for further analysis could not be accomplished.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The stock solution of theobromine for the synthesis of 4, 6, 7, and 8 was prepared as follows: Theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol) was suspended in 50 mL of H2O and brought into solution by addition of 6 mL of HClO4 (60%). The pH was adjusted to the desired values by addition of roughly 12.5 mL of NaOH solution (15%). pH values were controlled by a Bischof pH 24 pH-meter calibrated in the buffer solutions immediately before use. All pH adjustments described below were accomplished upon addition of HClO4 (60%) or NaOH (15%) solutions.

[Ag(thb)2]ClO4 (2)

Theobromine (122 mg, 0.68 mmol) was dissolved in MeOH (36 mL) by addition of HClO4 (60%, 4 mL). AgClO4 (70 mg, 0.34 mmol) in MeOH (34 mL) was added to this solution without stirring. The solution was left open in the dark and yielded colorless crystals within 10 days. The mother liquor was filtered off, and the crystals were washed twice with 10 mL portions of ice-cold MeOH and dried overnight over CaCl2 in a desiccator. Yield: 120 mg (0.21 mmol, 62%). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C14H16AgN8O8: C 29.72, H 2.49, N 19.80; found: C 29.32, H 2.94, N 20.38; IR: ν (cm-1) = 3470 (m), 3153 (m), 3123 (s), 3027 (s), 2883 (w), 2826 (s), 2750 (m), 2639 (m), 1697 (s), 1599 (s), 1551 (s), 1503 (s), 1458 (s), 1427 (s), 1365 (s), 1324 (m), 1289 (m), 1231 (s), 1201 (s), 1175 (s), 1102 (s), 1075 (s), 936 (w), 863 (m), 793 (m), 763 (m), 747 (m), 735 (m), 682 (s), 625 (s), 607 (m), 516 (s), 452 (s), 435 (m); UV/vis: λ (nm) = 201, 216, 277.

[Ag(thb)2(H2O)]ClO4 (3)

Theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol) was dissolved in 50 mL of water by addition of 6 mL of 60%-HClO4. AgClO4 (104 mg, 0.50 mmol) in water (50 mL) was added to this solution with stirring all at once. The solution was left open for two months, after which the mother liquor was filtered off, and the obtained colorless crystals were washed twice with 10 mL portions of cold water. 95 mg of 3 were obtained after drying overnight over CaCl2 in a desiccator. Yield: 95 mg (0.16 mmol, 32%). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C14H18AgClN8O9: C 29.60, H 2.82, N 19.73; found: C 28.25, H 3.00, N 19.72; IR: ν (cm-1) = 3582 (m), 3522 (m), 3371 (w), 3240 (s), 3122 (s), 3123 (s), 3070 (m), 2957 (w), 2827 (w), 2779 (w), 1695 (s), 1595 (s), 1551 (s), 1501 (s), 1464 (s), 1414 (m), 1366 (s), 1315 (w), 1285 (w), 1221 (s), 1082 (s), 937 (w), 874 (w), 789 (m), 744 (s), 681 (m), 615 (s), 515 (m), 449 (s).

[Ag(thb)2]2(H4V10O28)⋅3H2O (4)

NaVO3 (400 mg, 3.28 mmol) was suspended in 80 mL of the stock solution of theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol) of pH 4.0 and diluted with 12 mL of water. The suspension was heated to 55 °C, and the resulting pH of 5.4 was decreased to 2.6 by addition of 1.8 mL of aqueous HClO4 solution (2%). The red suspension was allowed to cool to 40 °C with stirring, and the resultant pH of 3.4 was decreased to 2.9 by addition of further 0.1 mL of aqueous HClO4 solution (2%). The yellow solution was separated from the red solid by filtration through medium-porosity filter paper. 50 mL of the aqueous solution of AgClO4 (104 mg, 0.50 mmol) was added very slowly to the reaction mixture. Orange crystals appeared after 8 days in the closed reaction vessel. Yield: 290 mg (0.15 mmol, 60% based on AgClO4). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C28H42Ag2N16O39V10: C 17.23, H 2.17, N 11.48; found: C 18.63, H 2.22, N 11.96; IR: ν (cm-1) = 3420 (br, s), 3165 (w), 3115 (m), 3032 (m), 2827 (m), 1695 (s), 1670 (s), 1593 (m), 1548 (s), 1487 (m), 1454 (m), 1367 (m), 1294 (m), 1225 (s), 1141 (s), 1112 (s), 1090 (s), 970 (m), 960 (m), 847 (m), 827 (m), 763 (w), 750 (w), 732 (w), 682 (m), 627 (m), 509 (w), 455 (m), 422 (w); UV/vis: λ (nm) = 207, 217, 277.

[Ag(thb)2]2(Cr2O7)⋅0.5H2O (5)

Theobromine (180 mg, 1.00 mmol) was dissolved in 50 mL of water by addition of 5 mL of 60%-HClO4. Na2Cr2O7 (262 mg, 1.00 mmol) was dissolved in 35 mL of H2O and added to the theobromine solution. AgClO4 (207 mg, 1.00 mmol) in water (50 mL) was added to the reaction mixture without stirring. After 1 day, orange block-shaped crystals precipitated. The mother liquor was decanted after 1 week, the crystals dried overnight over CaCl2 in a desiccator. Yield: 120 mg (0.10 mmol, 40% based on theobromine). Elemental analysis calcd. (%) for C28H33Ag2Cr2N16O15.5: C 28.75, H 2.74, N 19.17; found: C 27.70, H 3.14, N 19.53; IR: ν (cm-1) = 3601 (w), 3526 (w), 3119 (m), 3028 (s), 2826 (w), 2791 (m), 1707 (s), 1672 (s), 1601 (m), 1549 (s), 1468 (w), 1414 (w), 1363 (m), 1313 (m), 1288 (m), 1231 (m), 1198 (m), 1141 (m), 1082 (w), 1043 (w), 935 (s), 878 (w), 845 (w), 677 (m), 744 (m), 609 (m), 515 (m), 449 (m). UV/vis: λ (nm) = 205, 276, 380.

45 mL of the stock solution of theobromine (108 mg, 0.60 mmol) of pH 3.1 was added to the solution of Na2MoO4 (443 mg, 1.8 mmol) in 60 mL of water at pH 4.5. cln_elements.content:
The crystal structure of 8 contains a lattice built by Anderson anions interconnected by silver(I) in the c-axis direction and theobromine ligands connecting the silver(I)-POM chains in two orthogonal directions (Figure ). This lattice serves as a frame for voids of a cuboid shape (Figure b, ). These “boxes” measure (14.5 × 12.1 × 6.2) Å3, and each one includes 13 water molecules, 4 hydronium ions and one carbonate ion.

These interactions obviously become less significant with increasing temperature. A large evolution of heat is observed in the DTA curves of compounds 4–7 in the temperature range 240–300 °C (). This emission of heat is accompanied by a strong loss of mass in the TG curve (30–50%). Both observations can be explained by an exothermic intramolecular redox reaction in the course of which the ligand reduces Ag+ and POMs and is oxidized to gaseous products (most likely carbon dioxide, nitrogen, and water).

[Ag(thb)2]2(H3O)4[Ni(OH)6Mo6O18](CO3)⋅13H2O (8)

The crystal structure of 8 contains a lattice built by Anderson anions interconnected by silver(I) in the c-axis direction and theobromine ligands connecting the silver(I)-POM chains in two orthogonal directions (Figure ). This lattice serves as a frame for voids of a cuboid shape (Figure b, ). These "boxes" measure (14.5 × 12.1 × 6.2) Å3, and each one includes 13 water molecules, 4 hydronium ions and one carbonate ion.

These interactions obviously become less significant with increasing temperature. A large evolution of heat is observed in the DTA curves of compounds 4-7 in the temperature range 240-300 °C (). This emission of heat is accompanied by a strong loss of mass in the TG curve (30-50%). Both observations can be explained by an exothermic intramolecular redox reaction in the course of which the ligand reduces Ag+ and POMs and is oxidized to gaseous products (most likely carbon dioxide, nitrogen, and water).

cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Stability ranges of selected POMs in aqueous solutions.

cln_elements.content: (a) Amide-to-amide theobromine dimer joining two ditheobromine–silver(I) complexes in 2. (b) H-bonding framework of 3. The positions of oxygen atoms of perchlorate are split in a 50:50 ratio. Ag metallic gray, C gray, Cl green, H white, O red, split O magenta/rose.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Amide-to-amide theobromine dimer joining two ditheobromine-silver(I) complexes in 2. (b) H-bonding framework of 3. The positions of oxygen atoms of perchlorate are split in a 50:50 ratio. Ag metallic gray, C gray, Cl green, H white, O red, split O magenta/rose.

cln_elements.content: Parts of the crystal structure of 4. (a) Connection between the silver(I)-decavanadate(V) chains facilitated by hydrogen bonds between amide proton of theobromine and POM as well as carbonyl oxygen, water molecule, and POM. (b) The same interconnection accomplished by theobromine self-pairing. Vanadate: blue polyhedra; distances are given in Å.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Parts of the crystal structure of 4. (a) Connection between the silver(I)-decavanadate(V) chains facilitated by hydrogen bonds between amide proton of theobromine and POM as well as carbonyl oxygen, water molecule, and POM. (b) The same interconnection accomplished by theobromine self-pairing. Vanadate: blue polyhedra; distances are given in Å.

cln_elements.content: Ag(I)-Cr2O7 chains as part of the crystal structure of the room temperature modification of the 5. Cr: dark green; occupation of O-positions: dark red 64%, rose 36%, magenta 50%.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Ag(I)-Cr2O7 chains as part of the crystal structure of the room temperature modification of the 5. Cr: dark green; occupation of O-positions: dark red 64%, rose 36%, magenta 50%.

cln_elements.content: Silver(I)-dichromate chains in the low temperature modification of 5. Occupation of oxygen positions: dark red 79%, rose 21%.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Silver(I)-dichromate chains in the low temperature modification of 5. Occupation of oxygen positions: dark red 79%, rose 21%.

cln_elements.content: (a) Coordinative surrounding of octamolybdate(VI) in 6. (b) Silver(I)-octamolybdate(VI) chains with indicated H-bonds and stacking interactions between theobromine ligands. Molybdate: sea-green polyhedra.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  (a) Coordinative surrounding of octamolybdate(VI) in 6. (b) Silver(I)-octamolybdate(VI) chains with indicated H-bonds and stacking interactions between theobromine ligands. Molybdate: sea-green polyhedra.

cln_elements.content: Connection of [Cr(OH)6MoO18] chains by Ag+ ions and Ag(thb) fragments in 7. Only the main parts (70.7%) of the disordered Ag+ ions are shown.
cln_elements.clean_text: 8  Connection of [Cr(OH)6MoO18] chains by Ag+ ions and Ag(thb) fragments in 7. Only the main parts (70.7%) of the disordered Ag+ ions are shown.

cln_elements.content: (a) H-bonding framework in 8. (b) Molecular “boxes” built by Ag+-[Ni(OH)6Mo6O18]4– chains and theobromine ligands. The blue “bubbles” each include 13 water molecules, 4 hydronium ions, and 1 carbonate ion.
cln_elements.clean_text: 9  (a) H-bonding framework in 8. (b) Molecular "boxes" built by Ag+-[Ni(OH)6Mo6O18]4- chains and theobromine ligands. The blue "bubbles" each include 13 water molecules, 4 hydronium ions, and 1 carbonate ion.

cln_elements.content: Attractive and repulsive interactions between stacked theobromine molecules.

metadata.title:
A New Strategy for the Synthetic Assembly of Inorganic–Organic
Silver(I)-Polyoxometalate Hybrid Structures Employing Noncovalent
Interactions between Theobromine Ligands
